thread.title: Yankees have Billy Eppler’s replacement, but not an assistant GM
thread.title_full: Yankees have Billy Eppler’s replacement, but not an assistant GM | New York Post

author: George A. King III
title: Yankees have Billy Eppler’s replacement, but not an assistant GM
text:
KANSAS CITY. Mo. — Tim Naehring is going to fill the vacancy created when Billy Eppler left, but won’t have the title of assistant general manager attached to his name.
The Post’s Joel Sherman confirmed Naehring replacing Eppler, the former assistant GM who was hired by the Angels to be their GM.
Eppler’s title was VP, assistant GM with a heavy emphasis on professional scouting.
Hired by the Yankees in 2007 as a scout, Naehring has been one of GM Brian Cashman’s most trusted advisors on players the Yankees look to trade for or sign as free agents.
It was Naehring who recommended the Yankees acquire shortstop Didi Gregorius from the Diamondbacks, and after a slow start, Gregorius turned into a nice fit as Derek Jeter’s replacement.
Often times other organizations see Naehring at a game and conclude the Yankees are interested in somebody involved in the game.
There was some talk around the Angels that Eppler was going to take Jay Darnell and Naehring to Anaheim with him, but they were under contract to the Yankees.
Naehring, 48, played eight seasons in the big leagues with the Red Sox from 1990-97. He retired at 30 years old because of injury.
After retiring, he joined the Reds as director of player development and later served as minor league field coordinator. He was let go in 2007 when the Reds underwent a massive shakeup.
When Eppler left, Naehring’s name immediately surfaced as a replacement. So, too, did Kevin Reese, a former Yankees outfielder who served as director of professional scouting this past year.
